citations.narrative:
The facility uses carpets in the whelping kennels. In two of the kennels, totaling 1 adult female dog and 4 puppies, the
edges of the carpets are significantly frayed with long strings of carpet fibers hanging from the sides. Frayed carpet edges
can potentially be dangerous, as the dogs could chew on or ingest the carpet fibers, or they may wrap around the
extremities of the dogs resulting in injury. Correct by ensuring that all materials used in the kennels, such as carpeting,
are closely monitored and replaced when worn, to avoid the potential for injury. Correct by: October 1, 2023.

The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care for vaccinations. None of the 29 adult dogs are up to date on all
three of the required vaccinations (distemper, parvovirus, and rabies). Several dogs have no history of ever receiving
distemper and parvovirus vaccinations. Others last had a distemper and parvovirus vaccination on March 16, 2022, and
are therefore overdue. The current Program of Vet Care prescribes for the vaccinations to be performed yearly.
The following dogs have no record of receiving the distemper and parvovirus vaccinations:
- Female (F) Poodle #2847
- F Poodle #2845
- F Poodle #8177
- F Maltese #1896
- F Havanese #5900
- F Bichon #8162
- F Bichon #8178
- Male (M) Shih Tzu #6460
- F Bichon #5841
- M Havanese #2685
- F Maltese #2481
- F Maltese #2969
- M Maltese #2198
- M Bichon #3961
- F Bichon #0366
- F Bichon #70070
- M Shih Tzu #4059
- F Shih Tzu #5689
The following dogs last had the distemper and parvovirus vaccinations on March 16, 2022, and are overdue:
- Male (M) Poodle #7717
- Female (F) Poodle #5959
- F Poodle #5958
- F Maltese # 1886
- F Maltese #8179
- M Maltese #8499
- F Havanese #5904
- M Bichon #7447
- F Havanese #5894
- F Maltese #2493
- F Bichon #5841
Distemper and parvovirus are potentially life-threatening diseases to dogs and, if contracted, may cause pain, distress,
and suffering. It is also important for breeding females to be vaccinated as they will pass immunity to their offspring
through their milk. Correct by vaccinating for distemper and parvovirus in accordance with a schedule approved by the
Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer recommendations. Correct by: October 11, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.6(a)(2)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The facility uses carpets in the whelping kennels. In two of the kennels, totaling 1 adult female dog and 4 puppies, the 
edges of the carpets are significantly frayed with long strings of carpet fibers hanging from the sides. Frayed carpet edges 
can potentially be dangerous, as the dogs could chew on or ingest the carpet fibers, or they may wrap around the 
extremities of the dogs resulting in injury. Correct by ensuring that all materials used in the kennels, such as carpeting, 
are closely monitored and replaced when worn, to avoid the potential for injury. Correct by: October 1, 2023. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care for vaccinations. None of the 29 adult dogs are up to date on all 
three of the required vaccinations (distemper, parvovirus, and rabies). Several dogs have no history of ever receiving 
distemper and parvovirus vaccinations. Others last had a distemper and parvovirus vaccination on March 16, 2022, and 
are therefore overdue. The current Program of Vet Care prescribes for the vaccinations to be performed yearly.  
 
The following dogs have no record of receiving the distemper and parvovirus vaccinations: 
- Female (F) Poodle #2847 
- F Poodle #2845 
- F Poodle #8177 
- F Maltese #1896

The following dogs last had the distemper and parvovirus vaccinations on March 16, 2022, and are overdue:

Distemper and parvovirus are potentially life-threatening diseases to dogs and, if contracted, may cause pain, distress, 
and suffering. It is also important for breeding females to be vaccinated as they will pass immunity to their offspring 
through their milk. Correct by vaccinating for distemper and parvovirus in accordance with a schedule approved by the 
Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer recommendations. Correct by: October 11, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
